1: Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) is a private research university in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, United States. The institution was established in 1900 by Andrew Carnegie as the Carnegie Technical Schools. In 1912, it became the Carnegie Institute of Technology and began granting four-year degrees. In 1967, it merged with the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research to form Carnegie Mellon University.
2: The motto of Carnegie Mellon University is 'My heart is in the work,' a phrase originally written by Andrew Carnegie when he donated the funds to establish the Carnegie Technical Schools in Pittsburgh in 1900.
3: Kennywood, located in West Mifflin, southeast of Pittsburgh, is known as one of America's finest traditional amusement parks, featuring historic wooden roller coasters and family-friendly attractions. It has been a quintessential part of Pittsburgh's culture since its founding in 1898.
4: The Carnegie Mellon Neuroscience Institute promotes research combining neuroscience with AI, machine learning, and engineering. Notable projects include devices for individuals with locked-in syndrome, advanced brain imaging technologies using AI, and treatments for neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's.
5: Carnegie Mellon University enrolls approximately 16,335 students across its campuses as of 2023. This includes 7,604 undergraduates and 8,542 postgraduates, with students representing over 117 countries globally.
6: The Great Fire of Pittsburgh occurred in 1845, destroying 24 blocks of businesses, homes, and churches. It marked a turning point in Pittsburgh's urban development, prompting significant rebuilding efforts and reforms in city planning.
7: Pittsburgh is located at the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela rivers, which meet to form the Ohio River. This area, famously known as the 'Golden Triangle,' is a central feature of the city's geography and history.
8: The Pittsburgh Picklesburgh Festival is an annual event celebrating pickles and pickle-inspired foods. It takes place on the iconic Andy Warhol Bridge and features live music, food vendors, and family-friendly activities.
9: Carnegie Mellon's main campus spans 157.2 acres and is located five miles from downtown Pittsburgh. The campus is bordered by Schenley Park and the neighborhoods of Squirrel Hill, Shadyside, and Oakland.
10: Carnegie Mellon University boasts 21 Nobel laureates among its alumni and faculty. These laureates have contributed significantly to science, economics, and literature, further establishing the university’s reputation for academic excellence.
11: The Mellon Institute of Industrial Research was founded in 1913 by Andrew Mellon and Richard B. Mellon. It originally operated as part of the University of Pittsburgh before becoming an independent nonprofit organization in 1927.
12: Carnegie Mellon's athletic teams are known as the Tartans, reflecting Andrew Carnegie's Scottish heritage. The mascot, Scotty the Scottish Terrier, represents the university in NCAA Division III athletics.
13: The Robotics Institute at Carnegie Mellon has been a global leader in autonomous vehicle research. Notable projects include 'Boss,' the autonomous vehicle that won the DARPA Urban Challenge in 2007, and ongoing collaborations with industry leaders like Uber and Argo AI.
14: Undergraduate tuition for Carnegie Mellon students for the 2023-2024 academic year is $62,260, with an additional estimated cost of $17,468 for room and board.
15: The Pittsburgh Soul Food Festival was established in 2019 to celebrate the city's African-American culture and culinary traditions. The event features food vendors, live music, and community engagement activities.
16: The 'Fence' at Carnegie Mellon University is a campus tradition where student groups paint the structure overnight to express messages or promote events. The original wooden fence collapsed in the 1990s due to the weight of accumulated paint and was replaced with a concrete replica.
17: Andrew Carnegie envisioned the Carnegie Technical Schools as a vocational training institution for the working-class sons and daughters of Pittsburghers, many of whom were employed in his steel mills. His inspiration came from the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, New York.
18: The Tepper School of Business, named after alumnus David Tepper following significant donations, offers cutting-edge education in business, economics, and computational finance. The Tepper Quad, completed in 2018, serves as the center for business and interdisciplinary studies.
19: Phipps Conservatory and Botanical Gardens, located in Pittsburgh’s Schenley Park, spans 15 acres and features stunning seasonal flower shows, sustainable architecture, and educational programs. It is a key cultural attraction in the city.
20: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra will perform at Heinz Hall on March 15, 2025. The orchestra is renowned for its rich history and world-class performances, making it a cornerstone of Pittsburgh’s cultural scene.
21: According to the 2020 census, Pittsburgh’s population was 302,971. The city has experienced significant demographic shifts over the decades, reflecting its evolving economy and cultural landscape.
22: Carnegie Mellon’s School of Computer Science is consistently ranked as one of the top computer science programs globally. The school is known for its leadership in areas such as artificial intelligence, robotics, and programming languages.
23: Acrisure Stadium, formerly known as Heinz Field, is Pittsburgh’s professional football stadium and home to the Pittsburgh Steelers. It is located on the city’s North Shore, along the Ohio River.
24: Carnegie Mellon researchers recently developed a metric to measure gaps in EV charging infrastructure across the U.S. This research aims to guide policymakers in expanding the nation’s electric vehicle network.
25: The Carnegie Mellon University Library features a collection of rare works by Andrew Carnegie, the Mellon family archives, and digital resources such as the Universal Digital Library, which aims to preserve texts from around the globe.
26: The Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center, founded in 1986, is a collaborative effort between Carnegie Mellon University, the University of Pittsburgh, and Westinghouse Electric Company. It provides high-performance computing resources for scientific research.
27: Carnegie Mellon University is a member of the Association of American Universities (AAU) and holds space-grant status. These affiliations highlight the university’s commitment to research and academic excellence.
28: In 2022, U.S. News ranked Carnegie Mellon as having 23 graduate programs in the Top 10 nationwide, including Artificial Intelligence, Programming Languages, and Information and Technology Management.
29: Point State Park, located at the confluence of Pittsburgh’s three rivers, is a historical site that commemorates Fort Pitt and Fort Duquesne. It features a large fountain symbolizing the city’s heritage.
30: The top three most visited museums in Pittsburgh are the Carnegie Museum of Natural History, the Andy Warhol Museum, and the Heinz History Center, reflecting the city’s rich cultural and artistic legacy.
31: The Pittsburgh Life Sciences Greenhouse accelerates innovation by providing resources, investment capital, and support to life sciences startups in Pittsburgh. It aims to advance healthcare and biotechnology in the region.
32: The Bioelectronic Medicine Forum 2025 will take place in New York City on April 10, 2025. It focuses on the development of bioelectronic devices to advance healthcare, featuring leaders from academia and industry.
33: Carnegie Mellon University has had 13 Turing Award winners affiliated with its faculty and alumni. This prestigious award is often referred to as the 'Nobel Prize of Computing.'
34: Graduate tuition at Carnegie Mellon varies by program, but the average tuition cost for the 2023-2024 academic year is approximately $47,000, excluding additional fees for room, board, and resources.
35: Farnam Jahanian is the current president of Carnegie Mellon University, assuming the role in 2018 after serving as its provost. He is known for driving strategic initiatives to expand the university’s global impact.
36: The Mellon Institute building, completed in 1937, is a historic Pittsburgh landmark. It originally housed the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research and now serves as part of Carnegie Mellon University.
37: Carnegie Mellon and the University of Pittsburgh collaborate on numerous initiatives, including the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center, the Center for the Neural Basis of Cognition, and joint degree programs in computational biology.
38: The Gates Hillman Complex is a state-of-the-art facility at Carnegie Mellon University that houses the School of Computer Science. It includes 318 offices, labs, lecture halls, and a 255-seat auditorium.
39: The 2025 Fish Fry Festival in Pittsburgh is scheduled to take place every Friday during the Lenten season. It features traditional Pittsburgh-style fish sandwiches and other local delicacies.
40: The Randy Pausch Memorial Footbridge, named after the late CMU professor, connects the Gates Hillman Complex to the Purnell Center for the Arts. It symbolizes interdisciplinary collaboration at the university.
41: The student-to-faculty ratio at Carnegie Mellon University is 10:1, providing students with access to personalized mentorship and opportunities for research collaboration.
42: The Carnegie Mellon Cloud Lab initiative aims to create the world's first cloud-based laboratory in a university setting, enabling researchers to conduct experiments remotely using advanced automation technologies.
43: The Pittsburgh Pierogi Festival is an annual celebration of the city’s Eastern European heritage. It highlights pierogi-inspired dishes, live music, and artisan vendors in a family-friendly atmosphere.
44: The Heinz History Center in Pittsburgh features notable artifacts such as the original Mr. Rogers’ Neighborhood set, historic sports memorabilia, and exhibits showcasing Western Pennsylvania’s history.
45: The Bioelectronic Medicine Forum generates significant economic impact by fostering innovation in bioelectronic devices, attracting investment, and creating partnerships between academia and industry.
46: Carnegie Mellon University’s Qatar campus offers undergraduate degrees in computer science, business administration, and information systems. It is part of Education City in Doha and fosters global collaboration.
47: The Pittsburgh Picklesburgh Festival, established in 2015, celebrates pickle-inspired foods and local culture. It is held annually on the Andy Warhol Bridge and attracts visitors from across the region.
48: PPG Paints Arena in Pittsburgh will host concerts by major artists, including Taylor Swift and Imagine Dragons, in April 2025. The arena is a premier venue for entertainment in the city.
49: The Neurotech Leaders Forum 2025, scheduled for November 5-6, 2025, in San Francisco, will feature discussions on advancements in neurotechnology, including bioelectronic medicine and brain-device interfaces.
50: Carnegie Mellon University offers housing options for first-year students, including traditional dormitories, semi-suite rooms, and apartments in residence halls like Morewood Gardens and Stever House.
51: The "Like, Totally Transformative: CMU in the 1980s" exhibit is a snapshot of life on campus four decades ago.
52: The "Uncommon Perfection" exhibit begins on Friday, May 2.
53: The "Invisible Fight: Chronic Illness Support Group" provides support for students living with chronic illnesses.
54: The "Uncommon Perfection" exhibition highlights Derek Norman's work.

56: The "Charleston Battery at Pittsburgh Riverhounds" event will be on August 16, 2025, at 7:00 p.m.
57: Pride Month is recognized on June 7.
58: The lecture titled "Predatory Data: Eugenics in Big Tech" takes place on March 19 in the Tepper Building.
59: "A Gala of Grand Opera" will take place on Wednesday, April 2.
60: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra event featuring Beethoven and Mahler will be held on June 8, 2025.
61: The "Peter Pan" event at Benedum Center takes place on April 2, 2025.
62: The CMU Recent & Emerging Grads Virtual Career Fair occurs on April 18, 2025.
63: Spring Carnival has been one of the most anticipated weekends for more than 100 years.
64: The Black Women’s Support Group for graduate students meets virtually on April 4.
65: The exhibition "Here to Stay" celebrates 40 years of Pittsburgh's architectural history at Hunt Library.
66: National Arab American Heritage Month is observed on Wednesday, April 9.
67: Deb Roy is scheduled for the AI-SDM Seminar Series on April 4.
68: The "Invisible Fight" support group meets weekly on Tuesday, April 22.
69: "Heartfulness Weekly Meditation" focuses on well-being through meditation.
70: "Snackified and Cozy Study Jams" offers study support with snacks.

74: The "Libraries Workshop: Data Communication" event happens on March 19, 2025.

79: The "AI-SDM & S3D Joint Seminar: Tom Griffiths" is on Friday, April 25.

81: The University of Pittsburgh’s basketball games take place at the Peterson Events Center.
82: The Pittsburgh Thunderbirds play professional Ultimate Frisbee.
83: The Pittsburgh Steelers have won six NFL championships.
84: The Pittsburgh Riverhounds' supporters gather in the Steel Army section at Highmark Stadium.
85: The Terrible Towel was created by Myron Cope, the Pittsburgh Steelers’ radio broadcaster.
86: PNC Park offers baseball fans a view of the downtown Pittsburgh skyline.
87: The Pittsburgh Steelers won their sixth Super Bowl in 2009.
88: The Roberto Clemente Bridge near PNC Park is named after the first Pittsburgh Pirate to be honored with a ballpark naming.
89: When it first opened, PNC Park had a seating capacity of 38,362.
90: The Pittsburgh Pirates began playing at PNC Park in 2001.
91: The Immaculate Reception refers to a famous play in a 1972 Steelers playoff game against the Raiders.
92: The Pittsburgh Steelers are considered the most successful team in NFL history with six Super Bowl titles.
93: The first Pittsburgh Penguins game at PPG Paints Arena was played on October 7, 2010.
94: The first official Terrible Towel was waved at a Pittsburgh Steelers game in 1975.
95: The Pittsburgh Steelers are part of why Pittsburgh is known as the "City of Champions."
96: Only five home run balls have landed directly in the Allegheny River from PNC Park without bouncing.
97: The supporters of the Pittsburgh Riverhounds are known as the Steel Army.
98: The Pittsburgh Passion women’s football team has won a National Championship.
99: The Pittsburgh Steelers' fanbase is famously known as Steelers Nation.
100: PPG Paints Arena has a seating capacity of 18,387.
101: PNC Park opened in 2001 and is home to the Pittsburgh Pirates.
102: A riverhound is a nickname for the people who operate coal barges, not a type of dog.
103: The Roberto Clemente Museum is located in Engine House No. 25 in Pittsburgh.
104: Roberto Clemente is not only famous for his baseball career but also for his humanitarian work.
105: The Pittsburgh Passion women’s football team is internationally recognized for its success.
106: The Pittsburgh Penguins have won the Stanley Cup five times.
107: The record attendance at Acrisure Stadium is 70,622, set during the 2022 Backyard Brawl.
108: PNC Park has a seating capacity of 38,362.
109: The Pittsburgh Penguins’ sellout streak ended in 2021 after lasting 14 years.
110: The Steelers won their first Super Bowl in 1975.
111: What musical opportunities does Pittsburgh really have to offer for students? With artists such as Wiz Khalifa and Mac Miller laying their roots in Pittsburgh, a growing indie-music scene , and being one of the country’s most pronounced jazz cities , it’s only natural Pittsburgh boasts a rich music culture suited to entertain any audience. From the eccentric Stage AE to the stunning Symphony at Heinz Hall, Pittsburgh has it all, so get your listening ears ready for a tour of Pittsburgh’s music scene, from the perspective of a college student, 4-part Sonata style.
112: With artists such as **Wiz Khalifa and Mac Miller laying their roots in Pittsburgh**, a growing indie-music scene , and being one of the country’s most pronounced jazz cities , it’s only natural Pittsburgh boasts a rich music culture suited to entertain any audience.
113: From the **eccentric Stage AE** to the stunning Symphony at Heinz Hall, Pittsburgh has it all, so get your listening ears ready for a tour of Pittsburgh’s music scene, from the perspective of a college student, 4-part Sonata style.
114: From the eccentric Stage AE to the stunning **Symphony at Heinz Hall**, Pittsburgh has it all, so get your listening ears ready for a tour of Pittsburgh’s music scene, from the perspective of a college student, 4-part Sonata style. Other prominent groups include the River City Brass Band and Pittsburgh Youth Symphony Orchestra . The city also hosts a variety of smaller arts organizations, such as Pittsburgh Irish and Classical Theatre , Quantum Theatre , the Renaissance and Baroque Society of Pittsburgh , and Chatham Baroque , an early music ensemble. University choirs include the Pitt Men's Glee Club and Heinz Chapel Choir .
115: Movie buffs are likely familiar with Pittsburgh’s rich cinematic history, but **queer and other marginalized community films** often fly under the radar. At **Reel Q, Pittsburgh’s LGBTQ+ film festival**, we’re trying to change that.
116: We **became festival-official in 1985**, and shortly thereafter boasted of our “East Coast” premiere of My Own Private Idaho.
117: We became festival-official in 1985, and shortly thereafter **boasted of our “East Coast” premiere of My Own Private Idaho**.
118: In 2012, we **changed our name from Pittsburgh Lesbian and Gay Film Society to Reel Q in an effort to be more inclusive of the full LGBTQIA+ community**.
119: Originally conceived as a local space to showcase independent queer cinema that wasn’t readily available to mainstream audiences, Reel Q has remained committed to that mission, but also **upped the ante with the diversity of our programming, partners, and, of course, parties** (in the pre and post pandemic times).
120: The festival is a whirl-windy blast, featuring **meet-and-greets with cast members and directors, panel discussions, queer craft markets** and, did we mention the parties? This year’s celebration is scheduled for Oct. 6-15, 2023.
121: Catch us at City of Asylum for **Reel Stories , a free monthly series dedicated to showcasing international queer cinema, with a focus on marginalized perspectives**, which will be available in-person and virtually.
122: Author **Hannah W. Hannah Waltz** works on the Free Expression Programs team at PEN America, and currently calls Pittsburgh home. A true subscriber to the power of words and stories to promote good change, she's worked at the center of literature and activism at local nonprofits, bookstores and magazines in Pittsburgh, New York, and Indianapolis. **She's on the board of ReelQ, Pittsburgh’s LGBTQ+ film festival**, and believes in moving queer narratives to the fore.
123: Step into the world of thought-provoking dialogue and captivating stories at the **2024 Pittsburgh Humanities Festival , presented by Citizens** and a co-production of the Pittsburgh Humanities Festival and The Humanities Center at Carnegie Mellon University. Since its inception in 2015, this festival has been a **platform to explore the overlapping stories between the humanities and the arts**.
124: Step into the world of thought-provoking dialogue and captivating stories at the 2024 Pittsburgh Humanities Festival , **presented by Citizens** and a co-production of the Pittsburgh Humanities Festival and The Humanities Center at Carnegie Mellon University.
125: Step into the world of thought-provoking dialogue and captivating stories at the 2024 Pittsburgh Humanities Festival , presented by Citizens and **a co-production of the Pittsburgh Humanities Festival and The Humanities Center at Carnegie Mellon University**.
126: All performances are scheduled to begin at 7:30 p.m. each evening, from April 3-8, 2024, and will take place at the Greer Cabaret Theater in Pittsburgh’s Cultural District. Admission Entry to each performance is $25. **Tickets can be purchased in advance at trustarts.org or at the box office**.
127: Wheelchair accessible seating and **assistive listening devices may be available for each performance**, for questions contact the Pittsburgh Cultural Trust .
128: Join world-renowned researcher **Vincent Conitzer as he delves into the moral concerns surrounding artificial intelligence, exploring questions of morality, privacy, and fairness**.
129: Drawing from his James Beard Award-winning book, "**Soul Food: The Surprising Story of an American Cuisine, One Plate at a Time**," Adrian Miller uncovers the true history of soul food, tracing the cuisine’s origins from West Africa to the American West.
130: Chia Kwa of Whisperlodge invites you to learn about the evolution of ASMR, from its unrecognized presence in daily life to its transformation into a vibrant online community, culminating in **a live demonstration using binaural audio technology**.
131: Pittsburgh boasts a rich arts and culture scene, with a history dating back to 19th-century industrialists who commissioned and donated public works including Heinz Hall for the Performing Arts and the Benedum Center , home to the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra and Pittsburgh Opera . Other prominent groups include the River City Brass Band and Pittsburgh Youth Symphony Orchestra . The city also hosts a variety of smaller arts organizations, such as Pittsburgh Irish and Classical Theatre , Quantum Theatre , the Renaissance and Baroque Society of Pittsburgh , and Chatham Baroque , an early music ensemble. University choirs include the Pitt Men's Glee Club and Heinz Chapel Choir . The **Pittsburgh Ballet Theatre and Pittsburgh Dance Council offer diverse dance events**, while polka, folk, square, and round dancing are celebrated by the Duquesne University Tamburitzans , a multicultural academy dedicated to folk traditions. Pittsburgh is also a popular filming location, with major productions like The Dark Knight Rises filmed in Downtown, Oakland, and the North Shore. The city is also recognized as the birthplace of the modern zombie film genre after George A. Romero 's 1968 film Night of the Living Dead . Major **art museums include the Andy Warhol Museum , the Carnegie Museum of Art , The Frick Pittsburgh , Pittsburgh Center for the Arts , the Mattress Factory , and the Carnegie Museum of Natural History**.

140: In 2015, **Pittsburgh was listed among the "eleven most livable cities in the world" by Metropolis magazine**.
141: The **Economist ' s Global Liveability Ranking placed Pittsburgh as the most or second-most livable city in the United States in 2005, 2009, 2011, 2012, 2014, and 2018**.

144: The Pittsburgh Film Office also actively promotes the region as a location for movie, television and commercial productions and serves as a resource for visiting production companies.
145: Pittsburgh has produced numerous literary figures, including Pulitzer Prize winners such as Annie Dillard, Michael Chabon, and August Wilson, as well as writers like Willa Cather, Gertrude Stein, and John Edgar Wideman. The city also supports a thriving contemporary literary scene with various reading series, writing groups, and independent bookstores.
146: The **August Wilson House aims to preserve and celebrate the legacy of the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright** in his childhood home.
147: The city also supports a thriving contemporary literary scene with various reading series, **writing groups, such as PARSEC: Pittsburgh's Premiere Science Fiction Organization, Pittsburgh South Writes, and Pittsburgh Worldwrights**.

152: Your Suggested Itineraries: **Going Green in Pittsburgh Insider's Guide to Pittsburgh Redbuds Biking in Pittsburgh Pittsburgh Walking Tours 11 Things to Do on Pittsburgh's Three Rivers**
153: The Foodie The Lowdown: We love **pierogies so much that every Pirates game features a Pierogi Race at the bottom of the 5th**. (Go Jalapeno Hannah!)
154: You can find these little pockets of doughy goodness throughout the city in various preparations - pan fried and smothered with butter and onions, **vegan at top-ranked Apteka** and even dessert pierogi at PNC Park as you watch the Pirates.
155: Who Am I: This lunar rover is a perfect symbol of **Pittsburgh's evolution into a robotics and AI hotbed**. It's small and nimble, just like the city, and able to adapt to any challenges it runs into.
156: The Aesthete The Lowdown: Won't you be our guest? **Mister Rogers' Neighborhood was filmed here in Pittsburgh** - you can visit the puppets and sets at the Heinz History Center.
157: The Fan The Lowdown: The Terrible Towel was invented in 1975 when legendary announcer Myron Cope told people to bring yellow dish towels to wave at a playoff game. Who Am I: Often imitated and never duplicated, the **Terrible Towel is ubiquitous with the Pittsburgh sports scene** and represents the passion us locals have for all of our teams.
158: The theatre company is also well known for its annual **Theatre Festival in Black & White, in which white directors direct one-act plays by black playwrights and black directors direct one-act plays by white playwrights**.
159: Founded in 2003 by **artistic director Mark Clayton Southers**, the company originally held productions at the Penn Theater in Garfield and moved to a new space on Penn Avenue in Pittsburgh's Cultural District .
160: The theatre's mission is to develop and showcase **works by Pittsburgh playwrights, ranging from August Wilson and George Kaufman to new unknown playwrights**, and to "nurture a racially and culturally diverse community of playwrights, directors, actors and technical specialists to hone their craft and to network creative opportunities." The company has had premiere productions of works by such Pittsburgh playwrights as Tammy Ryan, Kim El, Marlon Youngblood, Brendon Bates, Wali Jamal, and Ray Werner.
